Please be aware that Germany and France are not comparable in this respect. France has a longstanding birthrate trend above the replacement rate, Germany does not. France (despite some internal backlash) has an assimilationist culture, Germany does not.

That a highly traditional and structured society could plummet to such a state in a short period of time is quite amazing. And your point about the younger generation being so devoid of ambition by contrast with the hordes of Japanese businessmen who were to be found in every nook and cranny of the US in the sixties in particular whose descendants have given up on the accomplishments of their kith and kin. At this rate of decline, if maintained, the Japanese nation as we now know it will be extinct by the turn of the century.

You might want to turn your attention to Europe to witness similar trends emerging and except for the traditional large families among resident Muslims the native populations are beginning to show similar strain. Germany and France have been mentioned as being concerned in particular.

You may not have any homework; as I biology major, I had very little (no?) work that resembled high school homework. What I had were readings, papers, and studying. Papers were collected and graded, but most of the other work was up for me to decide if I had done enough and "got it." Now I am a high school science teacher, and I try to assign relevant homework. But I'm still trying to find a way to communicate with my students that one of the keys to success after high school is transitioning from "I'm doing this because it was assigned and will be graded" to "I'm going to choose to do something because it will help understand this topic."

As a high school student, I feel very conflicted about the subject of homework. I feel it is a necessary evil that helps me learn and grow as a student, yet it has an emontional toll. Having hours of homework to come home to is depressing and disheartening. I wait for the school day to be over, then go home and do homework for hours. If I do not complete my homework, I feel depressed and disgusted with myself.  It is a cycle that truly takes the happiness out of the school week. On the other hand, when I am caught up on my homework, I feel accomplished and motivated.  It is interesting that the author is already thinking this way for her middle school son. The work load required to be an excellent student at the high school level is tremendous. I am pretty worried about how much homework there will be when I go to college. I should probably go start my chemistry homework now.

"In Greek mythology, Thanatos was the daemon personification of death....

The Greek poet Hesiod established in his Theogony that Thánatos is a son of Nyx (Night) and Erebos (Darkness) and twin of Hypnos (Sleep).
"And there the children of dark Night have their dwellings, Sleep and Death, awful gods. The glowing Sun never looks upon them with his beams, neither as he goes up into heaven, nor as he comes down from heaven. And the former of them roams peacefully over the earth and the sea's broad back and is kindly to men; but the other has a heart of iron, and his spirit within him is pitiless as bronze: whomsoever of men he has once seized he holds fast: and he is hateful even to the deathless gods." [3]

Homer also confirmed Hypnos and Thanatos as twin brothers in his epic poem, the Iliad, where they were charged by Zeus via Apollo with the swift delivery of the slain hero Sarpedon to his homeland of Lycia.
"Then (Apollon) gave him [Sarpedon] into the charge of swift messengers to carry him, of Hypnos and Thanatos, who are twin brothers, and these two presently laid him down within the rich countryside of broad Lycia." [4]

[3] Hesiod, Theogony 758 ff, trans. Evelyn-White, Greek epic C8th or C7th B.C.
[4] Homer, Iliad 16. 681 ff, trans. Lattimore ,Greek epic C8th B.C."

Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanatos

I agree Google should be punished for these privacy violations, however I do think that the mailbox analogy is wrong here. Our paper mail and mailboxes do not broadcast their contents to the public; unencrypted wifi networks do exactly that. While I don't like the idea of anyone collecting that data, it seems that responsibility for this situation extends to those who take no steps to secure their data in the first place.

Reply to Jonathan Silverman- so, if my mail is in my mailbox beside the street, and the Google Street View vehicle stops and reads it, maybe that's okay? Because it's out there, unprotected, right? Delivery isn't contained, inside my house, so according to you it's fair game.

More important here is that this kind of activity is 100% indicative of Google's goals, methods and (lack of ) ethics. And they hold the personal email of millions of people. Per your logic, because I willingly use them as my email provider, they have every right to use the nature and content of my email correspendence for any purpose. Because, after all, I willingly put it within their grasp.

Regarding the claim about "all sorts of data could be scooped up" is misleading.  The only data which could be gathered is the information in the WiFi packets being broadcast at the time the Street View car passed.  If anyone cares to see exactly what can be captured, the packet definitions are part of IEEE standards such as 802.xx.

"Even if a user was not working on a computer at the moment the Street View car slowly passed, if the device was on and the network was unencrypted, all sorts of information about what the user had been doing could be scooped up, data experts say.

“So how did this happen? Quite simply, it was a mistake,” a Google executive wrote on a company blog in 2010. “The project leaders did not want, and had no intention of using, payload data.”

But according to the report, the engineer suggested in his proposal that it was entirely intentional: “We are logging user traffic along with sufficient data to precisely triangulate their position at a given time, along with information about what they were doing.”

The part of the article which speaks about unwanted invasion of privacy of "potentially hundreds of millions" of people got my attention. What is the difference between doing this, and getting into millions of personal mailboxes, opening the mail and reading it, then cataloging everything. If someone had opened personal mail, that would be a federal offense.

Google should try following one of its own dictums "do no evil". I have no confidence in a company that says one thing, that was "accidental" and then the truth comes out. Recent proposed legislation where data gathering may be exchanged between corporations and government is also deeply troubling, short steps away from 1984.

How the Japanese deal with immigration is their own business and it is neither our problem to delve into, nor do we have a right to do so.

Immigration in the US is of two types. Legal, clearly by definition, in accordance with the laws of the United States and easily accomplished for the benefit of the US and the legal immigrant by their going to the US Embassy or Consulate in their country of origin, completing the application process, and taking ones place in line which, depending upon the needs of the US, may be a brief or long wait. That has been the law since 1921, with frequent updates. Today there are many millions of people worldwide waiting in that line in compliance with US law, and counting the days.

You refer disparagingly to the Republican Party since it advocates complying with the applicable laws of the US, and maintains that illegal alien immigrants are, from the moment they cross the US border, overstay a tourist, student or temporary worker visa, or for any other reason do not comply with US law, should be in fact exempt from complying with US law, though in fact they are criminals. There is no such person as an "undocumented alien". Such a manufactured PC compliant title is ludicrous. People who you may consider to fit such a description are always illegal alien immigrants.

Since the current administration flouts the law of the US, states have had to step into the breach. How SCOTUS deals with the issue will be interesting and likely not satisfy you.

Your first line got me thinking. As Mitt Romney has said, "Corporations are people, my friend". This is basically what the Supreme Court has also said in their Citizens United ruling. Here is the rub: people rarely live to be over 100 years old. Take a company like General Electric, which has been on the Dow Jones Industrial index for over 100 years. Among so many of the obvious differences between corporations and people, how does the esteemed, full of himself justice, Antonin Scalia, reconcile that fact in light of that ruling.
Will there be a new ruling from Scalia and his parrot, Clarence Thomas, that states: Corporations are just people that can live indefinitely, my friend ?

Life is short, people, if you're not an immortal corporation. Stand up for your rights while you still have that right. Ideas are bulletproof and nothing can stop an idea whose time has come. America's strength is not in a financial elite or in military force. Nature's prodigious fountain of life has endowed all people with inalienable rights and those who try to deny those rights weaken America. Human nature will not long tolerate tyranny. A captive media cannot stop us from thinking for ourselves. Our bought-and-paid-for Congress has refused to allow us to follow the money-- not only of terrorists, but of Congress themselves. Foxes don't like watchdogs in the chicken coop. Follow the money. Guess how many of the Republicans who started the debt crisis last summer sold short and, knowing when it would end, covered their positions with a tidy profit off our misfortune. I cannot believe that we, the people, would sell America to the highest bidder if we had a choice. Senator McCaskill honestly and compassionately represents all Missouri's people. She cannot be bought. The very fact that while most Americans are economically stressed and in need of money, the same folks who got the bailouts have bucks galore to spend on propaganda is revealing and incriminating.

They are also smart and perceptive enough to start realizing that, when the teachers and doctors all start ignoring dad and only ever talk to mom, there might be something wrong. Unfortunately, they don't have enough world experience to realize that something isn't with dad.

We recently published a study of gender equity in the Dept of Pediatrics at the U. of Colorado (Academic Medicine, Vol 87, pp 98-104, Jan 2012). We found unconscious bias to be among the multiple reasons for disparities between female and male faculty in career advancement, salaries, etc. Our research confirmed that even in a female-friendly field like pediatrics, unconscious bias in the professional sphere more often adversely affects women. Mr. Moskowitz's heartfelt description of unconscious bias in the parenting sphere is important to be aware of for anyone working with families. We shouldn't presume that parenting responsibilities rest primarily with moms, or that dads are less capable or competent caregivers. As a pediatrician myself, I know it takes effort - unconscious bias is powerful, and moms are the parents of record in most of our training and thinking.

But here's the important thing Mr. Moskowitz and dads like him, and like me, need to realize. The audience we should be most concerned about being visible to is our kids. How our parenting is seen in our kids' eyes trumps whatever their teachers, pediatricians, and babysitters see when they look at us. Mr. Moskowitz's son is already old enough to realize the kind of dad he has, and to feel the blessings of having two loving and committed parents. No bias from our kids. They are smart and perceptive enough to know love when they see it.

Amazingly, your comment has received the most recommendations, and yet, it has virtually nothing to do with the subject of the article, Apple.

You can't blame Apple for the "run down nature of downtown San Jose", as it's in Cupertino.

Can you show me the economic analysis showing that the "payback to the community is nowhere near commensurate" or is this just piling on since the momentum is in your favor?

Not all jobs in the US are manufacturing. There are also engineering jobs, management jobs, retail jobs. Apple has added over 30,000 jobs in the US, in the last 6 years or so. Don't those count? Apple has never had more than a few thousand manufacturing jobs in the US even when it manufactured here, so it can hardly have shipped more jobs than it has created in engineering, management and retail.

As for China, how do you know the jobs are "substandard" and for "little pay"? They're factory jobs. Yes, they're boring, hard, unpleasant. However, the pay is very good by Chinese factory standards, and the conditions, in general, are far superior. Have you ever been to a Chinese factory?

As far as lobbying goes, if you look at Apple's record, Apple does virtually no lobbying compared to its peers.

Sadly, you have written a fantastic rant about the general state of American dissatisfaction with big companies, but it has little basis in actual fact in regards to Apple.

"Governments are instituted among Men, deriving their just powers from the consent of the governed." A government is only legitimate, is only a government, so long as the people consent, at least tacitly, to the authority it exercises. When that is withdrawn, it becomes a tyranny.
